channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2012 The New York Times Company

item.title: Italy Grapples With Polluting by Ilva, a Giant Steel Maker
item.description: Citing serious health concerns, a court ordered sections of the giant Ilva plant closed, but the government issued a contradictory decree for production to continue.
item.dc:creator: By RACHEL DONADIO
item.media:credit: Alessandro Penso for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Ilva steel plant, in Taranto, Italy, above, employs thousands of workers but is seen as a health threat by residents and courts.

item.title: Morsi’s Concessions Fail to Quiet Egyptian Opponents
item.description: The Egyptian opposition signaled that it had given up hope of defeating the draft constitution at the polls and would opt instead to try to undermine the referendum’s legitimacy.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK
item.media:credit: Tara Todras-Whitehill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Egyptian Republican guards stood in front of a barrier near the presidential palace in Cairo, as protesters demonstrated against President Morsi on Sunday.

item.title: Plane Wreckage of Mexican-American Singer Jenni Rivera Found
item.description: A plane carrying Jenni Rivera and four other passengers crashed early Sunday morning in the mountains of northeastern Mexico. No survivors were immediately found.
item.dc:creator: By MARC SANTORA
item.media:description: Ms. Rivera recently won two Billboard Mexican Music Awards: Female Artist of the Year and Banda Album of the Year.

item.title: In Pursuit of John McAfee, Media Are Part of Story
item.description: A canny manipulator of the press, the software pioneer John McAfee teased many a reporter to his Central American lairs only to spin tales that were surreal and often unverifiable.
item.dc:creator: By JEFF WISE
item.media:description: John McAfee, the antivirus software pioneer, in a Reuters interview in Guatemala City last week.

item.title: News Analysis: U.N. Envoy Rice Faulted for Rwanda Tie in Congo Conflict
item.description: Critics say that the United States ambassador to the United Nations, Susan E. Rice, has failed to pressure Rwanda’s president to end his support for the rebel movement in Congo.
item.dc:creator: By HELENE COOPER
item.media:description: Congolese soldiers re-entered the city of Goma last Monday. Susan E. Rice, left, has been criticized for the United States’ role in the conflict

item.title: Chávez Put Party Unity Before Another Cancer Surgery
item.description: President Hugo Chávez of Venezuela postponed another procedure to solidify party support for his chosen successor, Vice President Nicolás Maduro.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM NEUMAN
item.media:credit: Presidencia, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Mr. Chávez kissed a crucifix during a televised interview on Saturday.

item.title: Iran Has Rosy View of Unrest in Syria
item.description: Iran’s leaders insist that the conflict in Syria, their main ally in the Arabic world, is manageable and ultimately will be resolved to their advantage.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: Changing of the Guard: Chinese Leader’s Visit to Shenzhen Hints at Reform
item.description: Xi Jinping, the new head of the Communist Party, made a visit to Shenzhen in south China, in a strong signal of support for greater market-oriented economic policies.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG
item.media:description: In November, Xi Jinping made his official debut as party chief at the 18th party congress, which military officers attended, above.

item.title: Damascus Is Tested as Clashes Draw Near
item.description: Through decades of repression, Syria’s capital held on to an atmosphere of tranquility, but the proximity of recent clashes has left residents afraid to leave their neighborhoods.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By an EMPLOYEE of THE NEW YORK TIMES in SYRIA and ANNE BARNARD
item.media:description: A member of Syria's symphony orchestra ahead of a concert in Damascus in November.

item.title: U.S. Drone Strike Kills a Commander for Al Qaeda in Pakistan
item.description: The militant, Abdel Rehman al-Hussainan, died in a missile attack on a house in North Waziristan, along the border with Afghanistan.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By ISMAIL KHAN

item.title: Birger Stromsheim, Who Aided Raid on Nazi Plant, Dies at 101
item.description: Mr. Stromsheim helped to destroy equipment that the Germans were using to produce what is known as heavy water, a crucial ingredient in making a nuclear weapon.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM YARDLEY

item.title: American Doctor, Dilip Joseph, Rescued in Afghanistan
item.description: An American doctor who had been kidnapped by the Taliban was rescued Sunday by coalition forces in eastern Afghanistan, officials said.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By SHARIFULLAH SAHAK and AZAM AHMED

item.title: Plane Believed to Be Singer's Found in Mexico
item.description: A small plane carrying the popular Mexican-American singer Jenni Rivera went missing Sunday after taking off from the city of Monterrey, said authorities in northern Mexico.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Susan Rice and Africa’s Despots
item.description: Susan E. Rice’s support for African despots over the years would make her a troubling selection for secretary of state.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By SALEM SOLOMON

item.title: Stalled Adoption Program in Guatemala Leaves Families in Limbo
item.description: Hundreds of children have been stranded in orphanages in Guatemala for years as authorities there weigh whether to approve their adoptions by families in the United States.
item.dc:creator: By RACHEL L. SWARNS
item.media:credit: Rodrigo Cruz for The New York Times
item.media:description: Amy and Rob Carr in Guatemala with Geovany Archilla Rodas, whom they have been trying to adopt since 2007.

item.title: Shintaro Ishihara, Right-Wing Japanese Politician, Makes Gains
item.description: Shintaro Ishihara, a novelist turned political firebrand, has emerged as a contender for prime minister and promises to restore Japan’s battered national pride.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER
item.media:description: Shintaro Ishihara, shown in Tokyo in November, is leading a newly formed populist party.

item.title: Protest of Nobel Peace Prize for E.U. Gets Local
item.description: At a time when joining the European Union is an unpopular idea among Norwegians, giving the union the Nobel Peace Prize brought out the protesters.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW HIGGINS

item.title: Romanians Vote in Parliamentary Elections
item.description: At the center of the election is a dispute between Prime Minister Victor Ponta and President Traian Basescu, who dislike each other intently.
item.dc:creator: By DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Changes to Agriculture Highlight Cuba’s Problems
item.description: Although the government has liberalized many aspects of agriculture, inefficiencies caused by central control mean that many Cubans are actually seeing less food at private markets.
item.dc:creator: By DAMIEN CAVE
item.media:description: Planting potatoes near Güira de Melena, a productive region not far from Havana. Much farming in Cuba remains low-tech because of a lack of machinery.

item.title: Letter From Washington: In Politics, More Can Mean Less
item.description: Fears that the fat cats, unshackled by a Supreme Court ruling, would buy the recent U.S. election proved wrong. Yet, despite the spending of $6 billion, voter turnout was down from four years ago.
item.dc:creator: By ALBERT R. HUNT | BLOOMBERG NEWS

item.title: Morsi Extends Compromise to Egyptian Opposition
item.description: President Mohamed Morsi of Egypt rescinded most of a temporary order elevating his authority but did not postpone a referendum on a draft constitution, a critical opposition demand.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK
item.media:credit: Tara Todras-Whitehill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters against President Mohamed Morsi next to a destroyed barricade near the presidential palace in Cairo on Saturday.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Art Basel Miami Beach: How the Art Fair Lifted a Neighborhood
item.description: The newfound allure of Wynwood is the latest testament to how art - and creative developers, like Tony Goldman, who helped remake SoHo and South Beach - can sprinkle its metaphysical magic and transform even the bleakest places.
item.dc:creator: By LIZETTE ALVAREZ

item.title: Syrian Rebels Tied to Al Qaeda Play Key Role in War
item.description: The United States faces a challenge, as some of the best fighters in an uprising that it wants to support belong to a group that it considers a terrorist organization.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By TIM ARANGO, ANNE BARNARD and HWAIDA SAAD
item.media:credit: Sana Handout, via European Pressphoto Agency
item.media:description: In May in Damascus, Syrian workers removed debris from two car bombs that were linked to the Qaeda-backed Nusra Front.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: 'Fragile' Australian Radio Hosts Get Counseling After Nurse's Death
item.description: Anger continued to swirl around a hoax call made to a London hospital by two Australian radio hosts who talked their way past a nurse to get a medical update on Kate Middleton. Three days later, the nurse was found dead in an apparent suicide. But some Australians are also defending the hosts, who are said to be "shattered" by the uproar.
item.dc:creator: By MARK MCDONALD
item.media:description: The Australian radio hosts Mel Greig and Michael Christian.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Reindeer Games in Hong Kong
item.description: A new Christmas video by CBRE in Hong Kong addresses one of the critical problems in Santa's supply chain.
item.dc:creator: By BETTINA WASSENER
